head.title: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?; Starr's Tactics Matter

hedline.hl1: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?; Starr's Tactics Matter

abstract.p: John J Maddox letter says Kenneth W Starr should be held accountable for his prosecutorial conduct, and admissability of any evidence in Clinton impeachment hearings should be treated as it would be in a legal proceeding (Oct 10 front-page article)

block.p: Re ''Next Step on Impeachment Path: Arguing About the Witness List'' (front page, Oct. 10):
The suggestion has been made that the tactics of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, don't matter because impeachment is a political, not a legal, process.
Re ''Next Step on Impeachment Path: Arguing About the Witness List'' (front page, Oct. 10):
The suggestion has been made that the tactics of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, don't matter because impeachment is a political, not a legal, process.
Yet nothing would diminish respect for the law or set a more dangerous precedent than to tolerate a lower standard of prosecutorial conduct for impeachment.

Mr. Starr's performance warrants serious scrutiny. If, as now appears, he has done more than simply exhibit astonishingly poor judgment, he should be held accountable, and the admissibility of any evidence treated as it would be in a legal proceeding.
JOHN J. MADDOX JR. Basking Ridge, N.J., Oct. 10, 1998
